source: Paediatric SVT flowchart (shock vs non-shock, vagal manoeuvres, adenosine dosing, DC cardioversion)
url: N/A (local copy in ED AI Tutor reference library)
when_to_use: Children with suspected SVT presenting with narrow-complex tachycardia, especially when considering vagal manoeuvres, adenosine, or DC cardioversion.

key_sections.summary: Determine if the child has poor perfusion, hypotension, or altered mental state. If shocked, prioritise immediate synchronised DC cardioversion.
Give synchronised DC shock 1 J/kg; if unsuccessful, increase to 2 J/kg and repeat as required. Call for senior/ICU/cardiology support early.

key_sections.section_title: Stable SVT – Vagal Manoeuvres and ECG
key_sections.summary: For stable children, obtain ECG, attempt vagal manoeuvres if appropriate, and assess for pre-excitation or alternative rhythms.

Give rapid IV adenosine via large-bore peripheral IV with 3-way tap and rapid flush. First dose 100 microg/kg (max 6 mg), second dose 200 microg/kg (max 12 mg), third dose 300 microg/kg (max 12 mg) at 2-minute intervals.
Ensure ECG trace is recording, warn child/parents about transient chest discomfort or flushing, and always insert cannula prior to drawing up adenosine to avoid spontaneous reversion.
If SVT persists after adenosine, consult cardiology for alternative therapies, reassess diagnosis, and consider further antiarrhythmic medications.
